executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2021 currency.

The Demolition Equipment Manufacturing industry produces machinery and attachments for the destruction and removal of buildings and other structures. Industry performance is closely tied to construction market trends, such as the level of private construction, as new property developments often involve demolition equipment to level existing buildings, as well as to clean up sites to prepare for new construction. Moreover, the industry is highly globalized and domestic manufacturers rely on exports for a significant share of revenue, in addition to steel inputs often imported from abroad. Over the five years to 2021, strong activity in downstream residential and nonresidential construction over the majority of the period has driven industry revenue growth. Resultingly, industry revenue has increased an annualized 3.0% to $12.1 billion over the five years to 2021.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry revenue grew at 3.0% annualized rate over past 5 years
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Demolition Equipment Manufacturing industry has experienced significant volatility over the five years to 2021, despite steady growth in downstream demand. Overall, industry revenue is expected to increase at an annualized rate of 3.0% to $12.1 billion over the five years to 2021.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growth hindered by US dollar appreciation and tariffs
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While growth in the total value of construction, namely residential construction, has largely benefitted industry operators over the past five years, industry performance has been hindered by the appreciation of the US dollar in recent years, tariffs imposed on steel and the economic slowdown following the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue grew 6.3% in 2021 due to economic recovery
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Revenue growth for the Demolition Equipment Manufacturing industry is expected to increase 6.3% in 2021 following a global economic recovery.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Moderate revenue growth of 1.3% annualized expected over next 5 years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2026, IBISWorld estimates industry revenue will increase an annualized 1.3% to total $12.9 billion.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Nonresidential construction projects to resume after pandemic
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2026, the industry is expected to grow, albeit moderately, as nonresidential construction projects, largely deterred by the pandemic, resume.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Infrastructure bill to prompt demand for construction equipment
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The November 2021 passage of the Biden Administration's $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill is expected to prompt demand for construction equipment amid increased investment in roads, bridges and other major projects.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures machinery and attachments for the destruction and removal of buildings and other structures. Industry products include backhoes, breakers, buckets, clamshells, cranes, dozers, excavators, forklifts, grapples, hammers, hoe rams and shears. Products are segmented among three major groups: vehicles and machines; equipment; and separately sold parts and attachments.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

key_trends: The residential housing market grew, with the number of housing starts rising as well
Industry exports and industry export revenue are expected to decline
The slight decline in enterprises reflects manufacturers' continued relocation abroad
Growth in the nonbuilding construction market will support demand
Industry manufacturers will experience moderate profit growth due to rising demand

market_segmentation.segment_description: Residential demolition is expected to account for the largest share of industry revenue in 2021, accounting for 45.3% of revenue in 2021. This segment includes the demolition of single-family housing and multi-family housing structures, typically for new construction.

The second-largest market segment is exports, which includes all foreign demand for residential, commercial and infrastructure demolition equipment. The share of revenue generated industry exports has declined over the past five years, falling from 22.4% in 2016 to 21.9% in 2021.

Commercial structure demolition is expected to account for 21.0% of revenue in 2021. This market includes office buildings, industrial factories and warehouses, retail structures and other commercial buildings (e.g., hotels and sports and entertainment venues).

The institutional and infrastructure demolition market, which includes demolition work performed on hospitals, schools, highways, bridges, roads and tunnels, is expected to account for 11.8% of industry revenue in 2021.

products_and_services.product_description: Demolition vehicles are classified as heavy wheeled and tracked machines, which typically require passenger guidance. Demolition vehicles include those that are characteristic of construction projects, such as backhoes, cranes, forklifts and excavators. The segment also includes vehicles equipped with specialized demolition parts, such as grapples and shears.

Demolition parts and attachments make up the second-largest share of industry revenue at 18.4%. Products in this segment include buckets, clamshells, crushers, grapples, hook hoists, shears, wrecking balls and containment systems.

Demolition equipment is composed of engine-driven appliances that are neither wheeled or tracked vehicles. This segment excludes equipment that works as parts and attachments. This segment includes stationary balers, breakers, conveyors and hammers (e.g., jackhammer).

tier_1_suppliers: Steel Rolling & Drawing in the US
Metal Stamping & Forging in the US
Engine & Turbine Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Power Tools & Other General Purpose Machinery Manufacturing in the US
Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Heavy Equipment Rental in the US
tier_2_buyers: Road & Highway Construction in the US
Bridge & Elevated Highway Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand for demolition and wrecking contractors
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for demolition equipment and machinery directly depends on demand for demolition and wrecking contractors. In turn, this demand relies on various US and international economic factors, particularly since a sizable share of revenue for the Demolition Equipment Manufacturing industry is derived from exported products.

Demand for wrecking and demolition services is driven by the need to redevelop brownfield sites (e.g., sites that contain existing buildings and structures), renovate existing buildings, replace nonbuilding structures (e.g., highways, industrial plants and piers) and clear property for new construction activities or environmental remediation and restoration.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Investment in building and infrastructure markets
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The principal drivers of investment into the building market include prevailing interest rates and the prevailing and expected property rental yield. They also involve the pace of general economic growth, growth in company profit and household income, and the level of consumer and investor confidence. Trends in public sector investment to meet long-term population growth and prevailing interest rate levels drive investment into the infrastructure (i.e., nonbuilding) construction market.

This industry is also influenced by demand for recycled building materials in the local construction markets. The reclaiming of materials and fixtures from demolition sites is an important source of demand. Recycled materials can be used as components of new or existing buildings or as infill (material that fills or is used to fill a hole) on-site development projects.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports are expected to increase at an annualized rate of 6.4% to $6.8 billion over the five years to 2021. IBISWorld estimates that imports' share of revenue will comprise 42.0% of domestic demand in 2021, an increase from 38.3% in 2016.
In 2021, the major sources of imports into the United States are expected to be Japan, Germany, South Korea and China.
Exports account for a significant share of industry revenue, with an estimated 21.9% of revenue generated from international markets.
In 2021, the major destinations for industry exports are expected to be Canada, Australia, Mexico and Chile.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region accounts for the largest share of industry establishments at 25.5%. Caterpillar Inc., one of the industry's largest players, has its headquarters in Illinois (6.7% of industry establishments) and more than half of its manufacturing plants in the Great Lakes region. Other major industry players, such as Komatsu Ltd., also have manufacturing operations in the Great Lakes region.

The Southeast region represents an estimated 20.8% of industry establishments. Large cities in these areas help contribute to their share of business locations. Property developers are more likely to look to brownfield developments in large cities (e.g. Atlanta), where the inner urban property values are elevated and the existing building stock is aging.

The West region represents an estimated 10.5% of industry establishments. Large cities in these areas help contribute to their share of business locations. Property developers are more likely to look to brownfield developments in large cities (e.g. San Francisco and Los Angeles), where the inner urban property values are elevated and the existing building stock is aging.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry is covered under federal, state and international environmental laws governing the use, transport and disposal of substances used for manufacturing machines and equipment.
The EPA oversees vehicle emission standards. Tighter restrictions on the emissions from machinery engines could also increase production costs.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, increasing barriers to entry.
The industry has high revenue volatility, increasing barriers.
The industry receives low and steady levels of assistance, maintaining barriers.
The industry is highly globalized and increasing, raising barriers.
The industry has high and increasing competition levels, increasing barriers.

factors_increased_barrier: Large capital investment required to operate
Strong brand recognition held by incumbents
Broad global markets and supplier contracts for incumbents
Scarcity of labor with required technical expertise

basis_points.basis_description: Competition based on price, quality, performance of products.
Efficient production processes and flexible labor agreements help keep costs down.
Efficient distribution arrangements and access to materials at competitive prices.
Customers assess total costs over equipment life including purchase, maintenance, running, downtime and resale value.
Products specified by consultants requiring compliance with US and international quality standards.
Some applications require very high-performance standards and specific capacities.
Energy efficiency important to reduce costs for energy-intensive machinery.
On-call servicing, warranties required for specialized, technical equipment.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Top 3 companies expected to account for 28.4% combined revenue share in 2021.
Industry leader Caterpillar accounts for estimated 24.5% of total revenue.
Merger and acquisition activity contributing to increased consolidation.
Consolidation improves profit by enabling higher machinery prices and production synergies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages represent the second largest expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages represent the second largest expense for industry operators, accounting for an estimated 11.0% of industry revenue in 2021, declining from 11.8% of revenue in 2016.

Purchase costs include those for raw inputs, such as steel and processed metals, electric wiring, engines, batteries and other miscellaneous part required to manufacture and assemble demolition machines.

Industry manufacturers rely heavily on capital equipment, as most manufacturing processes involve repetitive actions, often automated, to increase production speed, delivery times and cost and operational efficiencies.

Marketing costs account for a minimal share of industry revenue. Manufacturers of demolition equipment do not rely on marketing since industry equipment is a necessary component of construction processes.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Activity in the Demolition Equipment Manufacturing industry is characterized by a medium level of capital intensity. IBISWorld estimates for every $1.00 the industry spends on labor, an estimated $0.17 is allocated toward capital investments.

The manufacturing process requires significant capital in the form of plants, inputs and equipment. Most manufacturing processes involve repetitive actions that may be automated to increase production speed and cost efficiency.
Automated production lines rely on computer technology and robotic equipment to assemble parts and machines.

volatility_points.volatility_description: This volatility reflects changes in downstream construction activity, which is largely paired with demand for demolition work. The construction sector is highly cyclical, with activity following broader macroeconomic conditions.
During the period, revenue increased as much as 18.5% in 2017 as construction activity increased, while declining 9.6% in 2020 in the wake of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Demolition Equipment Manufacturing industry is expected to primarily contend with disruption related to the development of self-operating and automated machinery.

In an industry encompassing a wide range of products, companies use a range of technologies in the design and production of demolition machinery and equipment. Industry players register a large number of patents.
An ongoing trend has been electronic and hydraulic sophistication in excavators, giving them enhanced abilities in handling attachments.

FAQs.question: Do your sales depend on the overall health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Demolition equipment demand depends on overall level of construction, which is heavily dependent on the health of the economy.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Import penetration has risen in this industry due to the appreciation of the dollar, cutting into industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in steel prices has led to large swings in revenue throughout the period.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to key buying and selling markets?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers located in proximity to buying and selling markets will exhibit higher profitability, due to the large size of industry products making them more difficult to transport.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as 3D printing, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry mainly focus on innovating new products and technologies to gain a proprietary advantage.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers are increasingly investing in automation to reduce labor costs.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Tariffs in this industry are typically low, but industry products are covered under the set of tariffs recently implemented on Chinese imports.

FAQs.question: Have you had any regulatory expenses that have significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers have been investing heavily in creating new equipment compliant with more stringent emissions standards.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins have fallen for the industry over the past few years due to a sharp rise in steel prices.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Rising steel prices have dampened profit margins for the industry as a whole.

FAQs.question: How does your company make sure that it stays on top of the latest technology trends?
FAQs.answer: Access to technology, through a commitment to R&D activities or through licenses, is crucial for success.

FAQs.question: Do you have secure contracts with trustworthy suppliers? Have you had any issues securing or keeping contracts?
FAQs.answer: Supply contracts ensure that operators achieve the best rates on materials, due to the high use of industrial inputs.

FAQs.question: Has your company developed export markets? If so, is there capacity to increase export volumes?
FAQs.answer: Companies should develop export markets to expand revenue and diversify the sales base.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index? How have fluctuations in the value of the US dollar affected demand for your products?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of countries with which the US trades. The TWI is expected to decrease in 2018, however volatility of the TWI will continue to pose a potential threat to industry growth.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in housing starts? How have rising housing starts impacted your company's revenue?
FAQs.answer: A sizable portion of annual industry revenue is derived from work in the new residential building market (clearing existing sites for new construction), and trends in new housing starts point to demand for serviced land. The number of housing starts is expected to increase in 2018.

FAQs.question: How does demand from demolition affect your company's revenue? What percentage of demand comes from demolition and wrecking?
FAQs.answer: Demolition and wrecking contractors purchase an assortment of industry products to help them wreck and demolish buildings and structures. When demand for demolition and wrecking services increases, these contractors and services typically purchase more demolition equipment.
